instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00138: What is 820-00138? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.820-3662: What is 820-3662? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.SMC_BC_ACOK: What is SMC_BC_ACOK? This is identical to CHGR_ACOK. This will come out of the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging chip when CHGR_ACIN & CHGR_DCIN are present, and is necessary for the onewire circuit to begin working. On most Macbooks, CHGR_ACOK needs to be present in order for PP3V42_G3H to flow to the onewire circuit so that the circuitry that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC will turn on.  .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a
threads.message:
Have a liquid damaged 15" Retina. I'm going off the Schematic and BV for an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> which isn't exactly the same, seems like schematic isn't available yet.

I have magsafe lights but wont power on. I can feel <CHIP>U7330</CHIP> getting hot, will order in and replace, culprit of my <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>??


<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> - 0.6V
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3.38V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> - 1.13V
<SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL> - 3.2V
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> - 20.5V

<TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR>
PIN 1/3 - 0.643V
PIN 4 - 0.83V (<SIGNAL>CHGR_UGATE</SIGNAL>)
PIN 5 - 19.88V

<TRANSISTOR>Q7135</TRANSISTOR>
PIN 1/3 - GND
PIN 4 - 5.07V (<SIGNAL>CHGR_LGATE</SIGNAL>)
PIN 5 - 0.648V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a
threads.message: <CHIP>U7330</CHIP> probably shorted, this will also send PPBUS straight to the CPU. <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> needs to be replaced too and the CPU may also be fried.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a
threads.message: I have never seen one of these cases where <CHIP>U7330</CHIP>/<CHIP>U7320</CHIP>/<CHIP>U7310</CHIP> being shorted didn't kill the CPU. It is sadly the common failure mode on this model since it is right along the edge, and whatever is along the edge always gets fucked... and here the failure mode is killing a CPU that is worth as much as the board :(

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a
threads.message:
Thanks guys, sounds like mission impossible. I guess I will replace <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> and <CHIP>U7330</CHIP> and then see where its at.

Do you think Apple have a [I]Department of Liquid Damage [/I]who have the task of building boards that can maximize the damage caused by liquid intrusion :mad:
